subject: Sleep
title: Horses and Standing Sleep
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Horses and Standing Sleep.

hook.text: Horses can lock their legs and sleep standing up, but they can only dream while lying down.

buildup.text: A stay apparatus in the horse's legs allows tendons to lock joints, supporting body weight without muscle effort.

discovery.text: Horses get about three hours of sleep per day, mostly as short standing naps of N1 and N2 sleep.

twist.text: They need to lie down for REM sleep but are vulnerable when down. Herd members take turns lying down and standing guard.

climax.text: Horses that can't lie down safely, due to injury or isolation, become REM-deprived and eventually collapse from exhaustion.

punchline.text: Horses need a safe place to lie down. Their dreams depend on it.

quiz.question: Why must horses lie down periodically?
options: REM sleep only occurs when lying down, and REM deprivation causes collapse
